content: The National Commission on Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States (referred to as the "Commission") is established with the purpose of investigating the terrorist attacks. The Commission is established to investigate the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, report on the evidence, make a full accounting of the circumstances, and provide recommendations to prevent future acts of terrorism. The Commission investigating the 9/11 attacks is composed of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with restrictions on political party affiliation and government employment. The Commission investigating the 9/11 attacks is composed of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with restrictions on political party affiliation and government employment. It is recommended that appointed individuals should be prominent US citizens with expertise in professions like governmental service, law enforcement, armed services, legal practice, public administration, intelligence gathering, commerce, aviation, and foreign affairs. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Commission are elected by the members, with the requirement that they cannot be from the same political party. If 6 or more members are appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment, an initial meeting will be held. After the appointment of 6 or more members, the Commission can select a temporary Chairperson and Vice Chairperson to start operations, including hiring staff. The Commission will meet upon the call of the Chairperson or a majority of its members, with 6 members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission's functions include investigating the facts related to the 9/11 attacks, reviewing lessons learned, and submitting reports to the President and Congress. The Commission will determine recommendations for organization, coordination, and management arrangements related to intelligence agencies, law enforcement, diplomacy, immigration, border control, terrorist financing, commercial aviation, and other relevant sectors. The Commission has powers related to intelligence agencies, law enforcement, diplomacy, immigration, border control, terrorist financing, and commercial aviation. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and document production. Subpoenas can be served by designated individuals and enforced through the United States district court in cases of non-compliance. The Commission can issue orders to compel individuals to testify or produce evidence, with non-compliance punishable as contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures apply for witnesses failing to comply with subpoenas. Closed meetings can be held by the Commission as needed. The Commission may close portions of meetings for national security reasons, enter into contracts as needed, and request information from federal agencies. The General Services Administration must provide assistance to the Commission. General Services will provide administrative support and services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other departments and agencies of the United States can also offer assistance, funds, facilities, staff, and support services as authorized by law. The Commission can accept, use, and dispose of gifts or donations and use the United States mails. Members, subcommittees, and agents have specific powers granted to them. Members, subcommittees, and agents of the Commission may take actions authorized by the Commission. SEC. 6. STAFF OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. Additional staff may be appointed as needed without following certain civil service laws regarding appointments and pay rates. The Commission can appoint individuals as employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can also procure consultant services at specified rates. SEC. 7. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily equivalent of level IV Executive Schedule pay. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 8. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 8. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. The executive departments and agencies must cooperate with the Commission to provide appropriate security clearances to members and staff in a timely manner. No individual can access classified information under this provision without meeting the necessary security clearance qualifications. The Commission must submit an initial report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting, followed by a final report within 6 months of the initial report. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after the final report is submitted. The Commission can use the 60-day period after submitting its final report to conclude its activities, including testifying before Congress and disseminating the second report. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,000,000 authorized for the Commission to carry out the Act, available until expended.
